awd_abstract_narration:
This project is broadly concerned with the development of new techniques to study geometric and analytic problems on an important class of singular spaces. Geometry and mathematical physics have traditionally focused on smooth geometric objects called manifolds, but a slightly more general class of geometric objects called stratified spaces is equally ubiquitous. Despite this, only recently have specific techniques been developed appropriate to study detailed analytic problems on these spaces. One goal of this project is a continuation of the PI's long-term goal of establishing certain strong analytic techniques to study a wide variety of problems in geometric analysis which are set on such stratified spaces. Other goals of this project include applications of these techniques to problems occurring in gauge theory and in mathematical relativity. This has significant cross-disciplinary appeal between partial differential equations, geometric analysis and mathematical physics, and modulates between the parallel goals of developing general techniques and solving specific problems of interest in various disciplines.

Geometric microlocal analysis has emerged as a powerful tool to study a range of problems concerning differential and pseudodifferential operators with degeneracies. Such operators arise in many applications in geometric analysis and mathematical physics. The PI's current research interest centers on the development of a calculus of iterated edge pseudodifferential operators which can be used as an investigative tool to study elliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic operators on stratified pseudomanifolds. The ultimate goal in this is a theory paralleling and generalizing the Boutet de Monvel calculus, which provides the most general and natural setting to study elliptic boundary problems on manifolds with boundary. The PI intends to use this calculus to study specific problems, including Kaehler-Einstein metrics with edge singularities along normal crossing divisors and singular solutions of the Kapustin-Witten equations. Closely related research projects include a new approach to study the asymptotic geometry of certain gauge-theoretic moduli spaces, in particular the moduli space of solutions to the Hitchin equations on a Riemann surface, and the continuation of a program to understand the blowup profiles of families of solutions of the vacuum Einstein constraint equations in mathematical relativity.

por.por_cntn:
The PI's work straddles several parts of geometric analysis, a field which attempts to recast and solve geometric problems by framing them in the language of partial differential equations. The PI's research has become increasingly influenced by problems coming out of mathematical physics. This interaction has not only provided a trove of new areas of investigation but has also provided some rigorous justification for some conjectures coming out of physics. Notably, the PI and collaborators have made substantial progress on understanding some large-scale geometric structures of an object called the Hitchin moduli space. This structure had been conjectured by physicists and is relevant in string theory, but the PI's methods have turned out to be appropriate to a deeper understanding of this.  In another direction, the PI has been working to understand and verify some conjectures made by the mathematical physicsts Gaiotto and Witten about how a new gauge theory sheds new light on an important invariant of knotted curves. This has led to a number of new analytic techniques which should be helpful in the further elaboration of this theory.

The PI has investigated, more broadly, the way that partial differential equations which regulate the curvature of geometric objects (curves, surfaces, etc.) behave in the presence of singularities, e.g. if the curves form a network rather than a single curve, or if the surface has points where it is not smooth.  

Finally, the PI has worked on the theory of complete minimal surfaces in curved ambient spaces. Minimal surfaces are locally ones of least area, and complete means that they go off to infinity. There is sustained interest in understanding their nature and their geometry, and the PI's work has made some inroads into this in a particular setting. 

Throughout all of this, the techniques used in each of these problems involved the careful adaptation of an emerging set of tools which go by the name of geometric microlocal analysis, and which the PI has been one of the key developers, to study the partial differential equations in each of these settings. These geometric microlocal tools are particularly useful if the equations are on geometric objects which are not entirely smooth, but have certain well organized singular sets, e.g. boundaries, corners, conic points, edges, etc.  This is a very natural generalization of geometry for which classical tools often do not quite work.
